thread.title_full: Government to slash public service costs and help digital economy, says Communications Minister Mitch Fifield

title: Government to slash public service costs and help digital economy, says Communications Minister Mitch Fifield
text:
Rising levels of technology in government, and therefore self-service systems, is 'inevitable'. Photo: Louie Douvis
Communications Minister Mitch Fifield wants to deliver government services over the internet and ramp up technology education to make Australia the world's best digital economy.
Speaking at Telstra's 2015 Australian Digital Summit in Sydney on Monday, Senator Fifield said that slashing the time spent interacting physically or verbally with government staff also greatly increased satisfaction.
A service transacted over the phone costs about 16 times the digital equivalent.
Communications Minister Mitch Fifield "We have been unashamed about seeking influence from the private sector in the way that we go about digital transformation as we work towards being the leading digital economy in the world," he said.
Communications Minister Mitch Fifield. Photo: Andrew Meares
Slashing the number of physical and verbal interactions between Australians and public servants would provide a better service while dramatically cutting costs, he added.
Advertisement "We simply can't deny that the best interactions with governments are the ones that do not require a visit to a government office," Senator Fifield said. "Our mission is to overhaul the way the government delivers services to ensure that people can get the information they need when they need it.
"A service transacted over the phone costs about 16 times the digital equivalent, through the post, about 32 times and on face-to-face transactions it is about 42 times."
The Federal government under the previous Tony Abbott regime angered public service unions by slashing departmental budgets. Mr Fifield gave no indications that the rise of digital services would impact of staffing levels but was adamant that rising levels of technology in government, and therefore self-service systems, was inevitable.
"If we want to remain a prosperous economy with all of the benefits that go with that then digital transformation for government and business is not negotiable," he said. "We do have to pick up the pace in government and be more agile and to seize the opportunities that are before us."
